title: 49ers coach Kyle Shanahan on Redskins tumult: 'We'll watch other people deal with it'
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Lorenzo Reyes sat down with former NFL defensive end Chris Long to discuss the current state of social activism in professional sports. USA TODAY

The dysfunction surrounding the Washington Redskins is something Kyle Shanahan experienced firsthand while working under his dad, Mike, who was Washington's coach from 2010-13.

The younger Shanahan served as the offensive coordinator for those four seasons. When asked Wednesday about his favorite memory during his Redskins tenure, he responded "being able to work with my dad and be around some other good coaches."

A follow-up question came: the worst part?

"Everything else," he told reporters.

Shanahan quickly added that he enjoyed working with the players he coached in Washington.

Under Mike and Kyle Shanahan, the Redskins made one playoff appearance, when they won the NFC East in 2012. The Redskins hired Jay Gruden after they were both fired the next year. Gruden was canned following Week 5 this year.

"That was a while ago," Shanahan said. "I've been in three different buildings since. My dad retired. He's good. We've accepted what we had to deal with there and moved on. We'll watch other people deal with it."

In the conference call , Shanahan expanded on his previous comments regarding the organizational culture.

"I just learned it's very important to work with people that have the same intentions and you want to go in the same direction," Shanahan said. "Football is a very tough game, and no matter how close you are with people, there's adversity that faces everyone, and when you lose one game, two games in a row, you know what's going to be written and everything, and (if) people live off that type of stuff, it's very hard to survive and get through any tough times.

"You've got to make sure people are made of the same stuff you are, that have the same intention, same goals and they're ready to fight and work through things and see it to the end."

Shanahan eventually landed with the Atlanta Falcons as their offensive coordinator, and after a successful two-season stint there, was hired by the 49ers (5-0) in 2017. Through six weeks, San Francisco is one of two undefeated teams remaining in the NFL (the other being the New England Patriots).
description: San Francisco 49ers coach Kyle Shanahan doesn't look back on his days as a Washington Redskins assistant fondly, when he worked under his dad, Mike.
